Title:
New findings in the etiology of the gummy bark disease of
volkamer lemon rootstock in Egypt
Keywords:
Rootstock, viroids, mixed infection, molecular detection,
biological indexing.
Abstract:
The extensive replacement of the sour orange rootstock,
susceptible to Citrus Tristeza disease, with the tolerant Volkamer lemon
rootstock, in citrus-growing areas of North Africa and the Near East
triggered the emergence of a new serious citrus disease. This syndrome
is characterized by the typical stem pitting on the wood with gum
deposits in the bark of Volkamer lemon, similar to the viroid diseases
of the cachexia in mandarin and the gummy bark in sweet orange. Citrus
viroids have therefore been indicated as presumed causal agents of the
gummy bark disease of Volkamer lemon. This disease is devastating many
citrus groves in the newly reclaimed land of Egypt, where the Volkamer
lemon is largely used for its adaptability to arid zones. Molecular
investigations carried out in this study on symptomatic and asymptomatic
trees have confirmed the presence of different citrus viroids. Hop stunt
viroid (HSVd) and Citrus bark cracking (CBCVd) were the prevalent
viroids in the symptomatic trees, mainly as mixed infections. The
severity of symptoms in biological indexing (stem pitting and cracking),
induced by both agents indicated that the disease could be a result of a
synergic action of HSVd and CBCVd.
